screens.headline: Same trade, two traders: One makes $50k, one loses everything
screens.text: The difference? Position sizing. Trader A risked 5% per trade. Trader B risked 50%. Both had winning strategies. Only one survived the losing streak. Math determines survival.

screens.headline: What is Position Sizing?
screens.text: Position sizing = calculating HOW MUCH money to risk on each trade based on your account size and risk tolerance. Formula: Position Size = (Account Size √ó Risk %) √∑ Max Loss per Contract. Get this right = survive bad streaks. Get it wrong = blown account.

cards.definition: Percentage of total account you're willing to lose on one trade
cards.example: $10k account, 2% risk = $200 max loss per trade. If option costs $400, buy half a contract (not possible), so skip or risk 4%. Be disciplined.

cards.definition: Mathematical formula for optimal bet size
cards.example: Advanced traders use this: (Win% √ó Avg Win - Loss% √ó Avg Loss) √∑ Avg Win. Most retail traders stick to simpler 2-5% rule.

cards.definition: Risking too much of your account on one or few trades
cards.example: $5k account, buying 5 calls at $1k each = 100% of capital. One bad trade = account wiped. This kills more traders than bad strategy.

screens.headline: Think of your account like a business payroll
screens.text: You run a company with $100,000 in the bank. You need to pay 20 employees over the next year. How much do you pay each person per month?

reveal_sections.label: Pay $50k to first employee (50% of budget)
reveal_sections.content: Disaster! After 2 employees, you're broke. 18 employees unpaid. Company shuts down. This is overleveraging - one or two bad trades wipe you out.

reveal_sections.label: Pay $10k to first employee (10% of budget)
reveal_sections.content: Risky! After 10 employees, you're done. If any emergency happens, no buffer. This is trading with 10% risk per trade - no room for error.

reveal_sections.label: Pay $2k to first employee (2% of budget)
reveal_sections.content: Sustainable! You can pay 50 employees. Even if 10 are unproductive, you still survive. You have buffer for emergencies. This is 2% risk per trade - room to learn.

reveal_sections.label: This is position sizing
reveal_sections.content: Your trading account = company budget. Each trade = an employee. Spread risk across many 'employees' (trades). Survive bad hires, prosper from good ones.

screens.question: Account: $20,000. Risk tolerance: 3% per trade. How much should you risk per trade in dollars? (No $ or commas)
screens.explanation: $20,000 √ó 0.03 = $600 per trade. This means: if the option costs $600, buy 1 contract. If it costs $300, you could buy 2 contracts. If it costs $1,200, only buy 1 and you're risking 6% (decide if worth it).

screens.question: You have $10,000 and want to risk 2%. The call you want costs $500. How many contracts should you buy? (Just the number)
screens.hint: Risk amount = $10,000 √ó 0.02 = $200. Premium = $500. Contracts = Risk √∑ Premium (round down)
screens.explanation: $10k √ó 2% = $200 risk allowed. Option costs $500. $200 √∑ $500 = 0.4 contracts. You can't buy fractional contracts. Answer: 0 contracts - skip this trade OR accept that 1 contract = 5% risk (not recommended). Discipline matters!

screens.question: What happens if you consistently risk 10% per trade?
options: A 10-trade losing streak wipes you out
screens.explanation_correct: Math is brutal: 10% risk √ó 10 losses = 100% gone. Even 7 losses in a row puts you down 50%+. Recovering from -50% requires +100% gains. You're fighting uphill. This is why pros risk 2-5% - you can survive 20+ losses.
screens.explanation_wrong: The math of ruin: At 10% risk per trade, you need about 90%+ win rate to survive long term. Even great traders win 60-70%. One bad week (6-7 losses) can blow up your account. Lower risk = longer survival = eventual success.

screens.question: Two identical strategies. Trader A risks 2% per trade. Trader B risks 20%. Both hit a 10-trade losing streak. What happens?
options: A is down 20%, B is broke
Both are down the same amount
A is worse off than B
screens.explanation_correct: This is the power of position sizing! Trader A: 10 losses √ó 2% = -20% (still has 80% of account). Trader B: 20% + 20% + 20%... = basically $0 after 5 losses. Trader A can recover. Trader B is done. Survival is everything.
screens.explanation_wrong: Position sizing isn't about making more - it's about surviving. Trader A down 20% needs 25% gains to recover (achievable). Trader B is down 90%+ (needs 900% gains to recover - basically impossible). Lose less = win more. Counterintuitive but true.

screens.question: You have $8,000. Great setup on NVDA. Call costs $1,200. Your rule is 3% risk ($240). What do you do?
options: Buy 1 contract anyway - too good to pass up
Skip the trade - position size doesn't fit
screens.explanation_correct: Painful but correct! Discipline > opportunity. Yes, it might be a great trade, but $1,200 risk = 15% of your account. That breaks your rules. Breaking rules once = breaking them always. Skip it. Better opportunities will come that FIT your size.
screens.explanation_wrong: This is where most traders fail - they break rules for 'special' setups. $1,200 on $8k = 15% risk. One or two losses like this = permanent damage. The trade might work, but process > outcome. Stick to your 3% rule. Discipline = long-term success.

cards.back: Risk Per Trade = Account √ó Risk %. Contracts = Risk Per Trade √∑ Premium. Example: $10k account, 2% risk = $200. Option costs $400 = buy 0 contracts (skip trade or accept 4% risk).
Beginners: 1-2% (ultra-safe, learn without pain). Intermediate: 2-5% (balance growth/safety). Advanced: 3-7% (only with proven edge). Never >10% per trade. Ever.

cards.front: What if position size doesn't fit?
cards.back: Skip the trade. Yes, it's hard. Yes, you'll miss winners. But discipline keeps you alive for the NEXT 100 trades. There's always another opportunity that fits your size.

screens.badge_description: You know how to calculate proper position sizes!
screens.celebration_message: Incredible! You now have the math to survive long-term. Next: understanding liquidity so you can actually exit your trades.
